Graphical abstract Palladium-based catalysts are of key importance in organic synthesis due to their versatility and tolerance for a wide range of functional groups. However, their use challenged by increasing sustainability issues and complex preparation methods. Consequently, the development of new heterogeneous catalysts with enhanced sustainability is of significant interest. Typically, the synthesis of carbon supports for palladium is associated with high energy consumption or the generation of substantial chemical waste, prompting extensive research into the creation of sustainable biological supports. In this study, the potential use of aerobic bacterial cells as a support for palladium nanoparticles was explored, using Paracoccus yeei VKM B-3302 as a model organism. Electron microscopy, powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) studies demonstrated the formation of palladium particles on the cell surface as well as inside microorganisms following deposition from a solution. Control experiments established that bacterial cells do not interact with either the reactants or the products of selected cross-coupling processes. Furthermore, bacteria do not affect the analysis of reaction mixtures by nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy and gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS). At the same time, palladium/Paracoccus yeei demonstrated efficient catalysis of the Mizoroki-Heck and Suzuki-Miyaura reactions, yielding results comparable to commercial palladium on carbon (Pd/C) catalysts. Employing a fresh start procedure and catalyst separation method, the catalyst was successfully recycled and reused across five cycles, maintaining good catalytic activity. In a broader aspect, bacteria-supported biohybrid palladium catalysts can represent a new type of catalysts worth to explore in a number of processes, where sustainability issues are concerned. Keywords Biohybrid catalysts Pd/bacteria Transition metal catalysis Cross-coupling reactions Mizoroki-Heck reaction Suzuki-Miyaura reaction Data availability The data is available in the article and supplementary material. 1 Introduction The discovery of cross-coupling reactions in the latter half of the 20th century marked the beginning of a new era in organic synthesis, facilitating the creation of substances previously hard to synthesize through classical methods [1–4]. Palladium-based catalysts are particularly prominent in these reactions for their versatility and their ability to form carbon–carbon and carbon-heteroatom (P, S, N, O, etc.) bonds, enabling the direct incorporation of diverse structural elements into more complex molecular frameworks [5–13]. Cross-coupling reactions have wide applications in the synthesis of various substances with pre-defined structures and desired properties, including pharmaceuticals, synthetic hydrocarbons, dyes, pesticides, polymeric materials, and more [14–18]. The broad utility of catalytic cross-coupling systems not just from the range of metals that can participate in these reactions [19–22] but also from the presence of various catalytically active forms within the reaction mixtures, including heterogeneous nanoparticles to clusters of varying sizes and homogeneous metal complexes [23,24]. Heterogeneous catalytic systems, featuring active metal particles fixed on various supports, have gained special significance for sustainable development [25]. Their key advantage lies in providing a cost-effective means for stabilizing metal particles and facilitating catalyst regeneration, thereby minimizing waste [26,27]. Ideal supports should be stable, inert (not interfering with the synthesis or initiating side reactions), cost-effective, and environmentally safe. Presently, common supports for metal particles include different allotropes of carbon (such as activated carbon, graphene [28], carbon nanotubes and nanofibers [29]), various modified polymers [30,31], including biopolymers [1] (Fig. 1 A). Supports based on magnetic iron(III) oxide [32,33], silicon-based complexes [34,35] and other materials [36–39] were also studied. Activated carbon, characterized by a large specific surface area and a complex porous structure, is a notably inert material [40]. Carbon supports can be obtained from both fossil sources and agricultural raw materials (Fig. 1A) [41,42]. However, their preparation necessitates high temperatures (750 – 1500 °C) during carbonization and subsequent surface activation using an oxidizing agent or steam, followed by the deposition of metal particles onto the carbon surface (Fig. 1A). Large expenses of energy and resources accompany the entire production process. Furthermore, the final catalyst may contain impurities from other metals (Fig. 1A), and the poorly predictable structure and surface of commonly used activated carbon (batch to batch variations) can adversely impact reproducibility in catalysis [43,44]. An alternative method involves synthesizing supports from chemical precursors (Fig. 1B). This multistage process often generates substantial waste, posing environmental hazards (Fig. 1B). The resulting supports, which may include inorganic oxides, polymers, or organometallic complexes, can vary greatly in structure and properties [45–47]. Notably, the process of metal deposition on these synthesized supports typically consumes usually a large amount of energy (Fig. 1B). Overall, this method of support creation is not always environmentally friendly, given its numerous stages, reliance on chemical solvents, waste generation, and energy demands [48–50]. In alignment with the principles of Green Chemistry and the pursuit of sustainability, the quest for cost-optimized, efficient, and environmentally friendly systems constitutes a crucial area of contemporary research [51–54]. Supports derived from renewable plant materials or utilizing such materials are under extensive investigation. Examples include palladium particles immobilized on pomegranate peel [55,56] and the synthesis of supported Pd/Fe2O3 particles using chamomile extract [57]. However, employing cells and substances from plants is hindered by the need for prolonged cultivation and subsequent processing of plant biomass (which may be contaminated with metal ions from the soil). A more promising research direction appears to be the cultivation of rapidly growing microorganism cells for use as supports for catalytically active metal particles (Fig. 1C). This method is highly effective owing to the rapid and straightforward reproduction of microorganisms, which does not necessitate substantial energy cost and can be fully automated. Microorganism cells have been used as supports for palladium [58–61], copper [62] and other metal nanoparticles [63,64]. Incorporating palladium nanoparticles into the intracellular space of microorganisms or depositing them on their surface can yield heterogeneous catalysts relatively easily, without resorting to complex synthetic methods. For instance, such biohybrid materials can be synthesized through the enzymatic reduction of Pd(II) in cells at a low temperature [65–68]. The formation of metal nanoparticles via enzymatic reduction from salt solutions has been observed in the process of purifying heavy metal-contaminated industrial wastewater by microorganisms, thereby facilitating the recovery and reuse of valuable metals from waste [69,70]. Two methodologies for applying metal nanoparticles on or within microorganism cells have been delineated. The first involves placing cells in a nutrient medium containing a metal salt solution [71] and reducing substrates like glucose, formic acid, acetic acid, lactic acid, and their salts [72–74]. It is postulated that membrane-localized enzymes in microorganism cells consume these substrates, reducing metal ions to nanoparticles on the cell surface [75]. The location on the membrane prevents further aggregation of particles into large agglomerates due to proteins and other in microbial cells, which have a high affinity for metals. This affinity can prevent nanoparticle aggregation and allow control of their size without the need for toxic and/or expensive chemicals [60,65]. The second approach involves the use of pre-grown microorganism cell biomass [76,77], which is combined with a metal source (salt solution) and a reducing substrate. Notably, in addition to the substances previously mentioned, molecular hydrogen can also serve as a reductant in this method [76,78,79]. Similar to the first approach, the cells act as support for the metal particles, preventing them from aggregating. It is important to highlight that the process of metal particle formation on microbial cell surfaces can occur at room temperature and does not require extensive energy costs. Both strategies enable the production of metal particles either inside the cells [80] or on their surfaces [81]. The use of cells is complicated by the fact that metals in large quantities can inhibit the growth of microorganisms. Therefore, the capacity of certain microorganism strains to adapt and tolerate high concentrations of metal salts holds significant potential for their use as platforms for nanoparticle preparation. This tolerance in some microorganisms to heavy metal salts is due to their protective mechanisms, which convert hazardous metal species into less toxic forms of nanoparticles, or their ability to utilize metals as electron acceptors in metabolic pathways. We previously isolated and characterized a strain of aerobic bacteria, Paracoccus yeei VKM B-3302 (P. yeei), from active sludge, and deposited it in the VKM (All-Russian Collection of Microorganisms) database [82]. We assumed that this microorganism strain is could biotransform initial Pd salts into metal nanoparticles with their subsequent accumulation on the cell surface or into the intracellular space. Additionally, cells of microorganisms isolated from active sludge are likely more resistant to various pollutants, including the toxicity of organic substances and solvents. Since the search for new available and effective catalysts is currently one of the main areas of research in organic and organometallic chemistry, such sustainable bacterial cell-derived supports can be considered high-potential materials for the preparation of biohybrid heterogeneous catalysts. The novelty and significance of the present study deserve brief mention. Herein, we demonstrate, for the first time, the feasibility of using the aerobic microorganism P. yeei as a stable and inert support for the creation of novel Pd/P. yeei materials (Fig. 1C), which are suitable for facilitating crucial cross-coupling reactions. Advancements in employing bacteria as supports for Pd nanoparticles can significantly reduce the cost of catalysts by the high growth rate of cell biomass, creating new advantages in the recovery of used metal catalysts. Beyond the development of the novel Pd/P. yeei catalyst, we also introduce an overall methodology for a series of tests to assess biotechnological metal-on(in)-bacteria catalysts for the first time. This approach holds special interest for sustainable development and in the field of organic synthesis. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Overall methodology to study the applicability of Pd/bacteria as catalysts In this research, we explored the principal possibility of using Paracoccus yeei VKM B-3302 bacterial cells as supports for palladium nanoparticles, aiming for their subsequent application as catalysts in the widely utilized the Suzuki-Miyaura and Mizoroki-Heck reactions. Paracoccus yeei bacteria exhibit a high growth rate, simplicity in reproduction and maintenance in pure culture. Additionally, these bacterial cells are small in size (up to 1 µm) and have a consistent coccus shape [83]. They also maintain physiological activity at relatively high concentrations of heavy metals [84]. These characteristics enable the effective use of these microorganisms as supports for Pd nanoparticles facilitating a high density of metal nanoparticles per volume unit of support. In this study, we systematically examined the reliability of using bacterial cells as sustainable supports for palladium catalysts, addressing the following essential aspects (Fig. 2 ): – Deposition of palladium nanoparticles on bacterial cells (Section 2.2); – Tolerance of microbial cells to the initial reagents (Section 2.3); – Influence of P. yeei cells on the analysis of the reaction mixture by NMR spectroscopy (Section 2.3); – Tolerance of bacterial cells towards the reaction product (Section 2.4); – Applicability of palladium/bacteria catalysts for cross-coupling reactions (Section 2.5); – Universality of biohybrid Pd/bacteria for synthetic applications (Section 2.6); – Recycling test for the Pd/bacteria catalyst (Section 2.7); – Assessment of Pd leaching from the bacterial support (Section 2.8); – Effect of bacteria on the course of the reaction (Section 2.9). 2.2 Preparation and characterization of the Pd/bacteria biohybrid catalyst To answer the questions outlined in Fig. 2, we synthesized Pd/Paracoccus yeei (Pd/P. yeei) using the following method. The biomass of cells was mixed with Pd salt in distilled water. Hydrogen was then purged through the mixture for a specified duration. Subsequently, the Pd/bacteria material was separated by centrifugation (see Supporting Information for details). This prepared biohybrid was then ready for structural studies and further use in catalysis. Electron microscopy is a convenient and widely used technique for the characterization of complex materials such as Pd/bacteria. The use of modern microscopes with cold field-emission (CFE or FE) electron sources makes it possible to achieve relatively high spatial resolution. In the current study, bacterial cells without metal and with 5 wt% palladium were visualized with the use of FE–SEM operating in backscattered electron (BSE) mode to achieve compositional contrast on the obtained microphotographs that allowed us to distinguish particles containing heavy palladium from a matrix consisting of light elements such as carbon, nitrogen, oxygen and others (Fig. 3 ). Upon vacuum drying, initial bacterial cells appeared in BSE-SEM images as slightly distorted spheres with a diameter of about 1 µm, tightly aggregated together (Fig. 3A). The arrangement of cells was rather regular, and the alignment of individual sample units in rows and columns was observed in the obtained SEM images. No significant fluctuations in the contrast were presented on microphotographs, which indicated the homogeneity of the sample on the selected scale. Notable changes in material morphology were observed following palladium deposition. Microscale electron microscopy demonstrated the appearance of large crystalline particles with sizes of approximately 1 – 5 µm (Fig. 3B and C). The positive contrast between these particles and surrounding bacteria revealed the presence of heavy elements, most likely palladium, in the microsized inclusions. A possible explanation for the observed effect can be both the tendency of the resulting metallic particles to aggregate and the limited solubility of the initial metal salt under the catalyst preparation conditions. The structure of the cell aggregates after the deposition of the metal underwent a tangible change. Regular rows of cells, especially in places where the presence of palladium was detected, were replaced by microstructures that were more chaotic. Promising results were obtained from BSE-SEM analysis at the sub-micro level. In the case of pure bacterial cells, no extra morphological information was obtained. The increase in magnification allowed observation of the presence of slight internal structural inhomogeneity within the sample particles (Fig. 3D). A completely different picture was observed in the case of Pd/P. yeei. The strong positive compositional contact between the biosupport and the metallic phase made it possible to visualize the nanosized palladium shell covering the bacterial cells (Fig. 3E and F). A detailed analysis of the morphology of the shell showed that it consisted of near-spherical particles, or more precisely unresolved aggregates, ranging in size from approximately 10 to 50 nm (Fig. 3G). Therefore, scanning electron microscopy with backscattered electron detection confirmed the deposition of palladium on bacterial cells, illustrated the nature and localization of the palladium-containing phase, and visualized small aggregates of metallic palladium several tens of nanometers in size. To independently verify the distribution of palladium in Pd/bacteria, the hybrid material sample was subjected to energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) analysis (Fig. 4 ). A number of signals corresponding to the typical nonmetallic (C, N, O, P, and S) and metallic (Na, Mg, and K) biogenic elements were observed in the EDX spectrum for Pd/P. yeei (see Supporting information). Additionally, the presence in the spectrum of the intense lines corresponding to the L-series of palladium indicated the incorporation of the target catalytically active metal into or onto bacterial cells. Elemental mapping (Fig. 4) clearly demonstrated that biogenic elements such as carbon, oxygen, and phosphorous were uniformly distributed across the sample surface at the microscale. Inhomogeneities on the maps for these elements, especially noticeable in the case of light elements (C and O), were caused only by the developed topography of the sample. In turn, the element map for palladium demonstrated the existence of microsized Pd-enriched regions in the sample (Fig. 4), which was in complete agreement with the results of BSE-SEM measurements (Fig. 3B and C). Smaller palladium nanoparticles were not visualized with the use of EDX mapping, likely due to their small contribution to the intensity of the corresponding signal in the spectrum. Thus, electron microscopy and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy confirmed the presence of palladium in the prepared catalyst in two different forms: nanosized Pd(0) particles and their small aggregates (less than 100 nm), as well as microsized crystalline inclusions, probably containing Pd(II) species. It should be emphasized that not all areas of Pd/P. yeei were uniformly covered with palladium, which may require further optimization of the biohybrid material preparation methods. As another possibility, it should not be excluded that Pd particles may be located between bacterial cells. Detailed study of Pd/P. yeei catalyst morphology at the nanoparticle level was carried out using bright-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (BF–STEM). To visualize the internal structure of bacterial cells in the prepared biohybrid material, the sample was sectioned with an ultramicrotome prior to BF–STEM imaging. Electron microscopy clearly demonstrated the presence of small palladium nanoparticles and their aggregates in Pd/P. yeei catalyst (Fig. 5 A-C). The metallic species were located at different sites of the sample: on the surface of bacterial cells (Fig. 5B, Site 1), between individual cells in the sarcina (Fig. 5B, Site 2) and inside bacterial cells (Fig. 5B, Site 3). The size of the Pd NPs varied dependent on the location of the particles. Large particles and aggregates were detected exclusively outside bacterial cells, whereas small nanoparticles several nanometers in size predominated inside microorganisms. To more accurately quantify the observed patterns, comparative statistical analysis was performed (Fig. 5D-F). Palladium nanoparticles on the surface of bacterial cells had a mean diameter of 4.9 nm (Fig. 5D). This size was notably lower for particles located between cells in the sarcina or dispersed inside bacterial cells and amounted to 3.7 nm and 2.8 nm, respectively (Fig. 5E-F). Thus, the BF–STEM study demonstrated the existence of small nanosized palladium particles in the biohybrid material capable of promoting the target chemical transformations. In addition, it was clearly shown that the bacterial cell environment can act as an efficient stabilizer for active metallic species, which can be considered a distinguishing feature of this bio-derived catalyst support. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis of the prepared Pd/P. yeei catalyst confirmed the presence of Pd (0) on the bacterial cells (details provided in the Supporting Information). The presence of PdO in the biohybrid material is an interesting fact and can be explained by the stimulation of palladium oxide formation under the action of bioorganic substances located on the bacterial surface. XPS lines corresponded to Pd (II) salt were also detected. Compared with a common Pd/C catalyst, the metal forms on bacterial cells and carbon are the same since the binding energies of the peaks do not differ significantly. 2.3 Testing the tolerance of cells towards the starting materials and checking the influence of cells on NMR analysis To assess the potential interaction of bacterial cells with initial reagents and their interfering in analyzing reaction mixtures by NMR spectroscopy, control reactions without a catalyst were carried out. Coupling partners (iodobenzene and styrene for the Mizoroki-Heck reaction; iodobenzene and phenylboronic acid for the Suzuki-Miyaura reaction) were mixed with cells and stirred for 1 h at room temperature. The reaction mixtures were then subjected to 1H NMR spectroscopy, using an external standard. The only observable effect in this experiment was an increase in water content within the reaction mixtures. Furthermore, the mixtures were placed in model conditions and stirred under heating for 3 and 5 h for the Suzuki-Miyaura and Mizoroki-Heck reactions, respectively. Subsequent 1H NMR spectroscopy confirmed the absence of reactions between the microorganisms and the initial reagents that could lead to the formation of undesired byproducts. Importantly, bacterial cells did not interfere with the 1H NMR spectroscopy analysis. 2.4 Testing the tolerance of bacterial cells towards the reaction products A dedicated experiment was carried out to exclude the possibility of microbial cell interaction with the reaction products. During this experiment, cells were mixed with an isolated product of a model reaction (stilbene for the Mizoroki-Heck reaction, diphenyl for the Suzuki-Miyaura reaction) and then stirred under heat for the duration of the corresponding reaction. After completion, the reaction product was isolated, and 1H NMR spectrum was recorded to evaluate product purity. Despite minor material losses during the experiment (residues were 81 % and 89 % compared to the initial quantities for stilbene and diphenyl, respectively), the substances did not undergo significant transformations after stirring and heating with the bacterial cells. The only exception was the appearance small peaks in the aliphatic region on the 1H NMR spectrum. This evidence may indicate partial destruction and dissolution of microorganisms upon heating. However, these impurities do not interact with the substances under study, and most of the cell residues can be easily filtered out after completion of the reaction. 2.5 Evaluating Pd/bacteria in model reaction conditions for the Mizoroki-Heck and Suzuki-Miyaura couplings For a preliminary assessment of the possibility of using palladium nanoparticles deposited on microbial cells as catalysts in organic synthesis, we carried out the Mizoroki-Heck and Suzuki-Miyaura reactions under model conditions with Pd/bacteria as a potential catalyst (Scheme 1 ). Prepared Pd/P. yeei biohybrid catalyst (1 mol.%) and a similar commercially available Pd on activated carbon catalyst (1 mol.%, Pd/C) were used in the comparative study, both as 5 wt% materials. The completeness of the initial iodobenzene conversion was determined using GC–MS. For all reactions, complete (over 95 %) conversion of the starting substances was observed, both with our biohybrid catalyst and with the commercial catalyst under the model conditions. Despite the slightly lower isolated product yields, in both studied reactions, microorganism-based biohybrid catalysts demonstrated a high efficiency comparable to that of commercial catalysts (Table 1 ). 2.6 Investigating Pd/bacteria as a catalyst for organic synthesis reactions To demonstrate the versatility of the developed biohybrid material, we tested Pd/bacteria as a catalyst for the model Mizoroki-Heck and Suzuki-Miyaura reactions with various substrates. Each reaction was repeated four times to ensure reproducibility. The yields were processed considering a confidence probability P = 0.95 and n = 4, with the average yield and confidence interval calculated. Table 1 lists the substrates used and the corresponding obtained yields. In the Suzuki-Miyaura coupling, the yields using the Pd/P. yeei catalyst were generally higher than those with commercial Pd/C, except in the reaction of 4-iodomethylbenzoate with 4-methylphenylboronic acid (91% for Pd/C; 86% for Pd/bacteria). Yield differences between Pd/bacteria and Pd/C ranged from 3 to 11 % (for phenylboronic acid) and from 5 to 20 % (for 4-methylphenylboronic acid), depending on the coupling partner. Fig. 6 illustrates the statistical analysis results. In the Mizoroki-Heck reaction with 1-iodo-4-nitrobenzene and butyl acrylate Pd/P. yeei and Pd/C catalysts showed commensurate results (94 and 94 %). Considering the confidence interval (Fig. 6), the biohybrid catalyst outperformed commercial Pd/C in reactions butylacrylate with iodobenzene, 4-iodomethylbenzoate, and bromobenzene (by 4, 5, and 8 %, respectively). However, with 1-iodo-4-methoxybenzene and alkenes, higher average yields were achieved using the commercial catalyst. A possible explanation is that cells as a support release catalytically active Pd particles faster than activated carbon. Therefore, more reactive substrates (iodobenzene; 1-iodo-4-nitrobenzene) provide comparable yields, while less reactive substrates (4-iodomethylbenzoate; bromobenzene) provide even greater yields when using microorganism cells as a support. However, this assumption requires further investigation, especially considering that the interaction of 1-iodo-4-methoxybenzene with butyl acrylate proceeds better with Pd/C as the catalyst. In the Mizoroki-Heck reactions with less reactive styrene, high to quantitative yields were observed with commercial Pd/C and with prepared Pd/bacteria catalysts, which may be indirect evidence of the aforementioned assumption of faster release of nanoparticles from a carbon support. Considering the confidence intervals, the reaction yields with different catalysts are comparable. Notably, Pd/P. yeei is capable of catalyzing cross-coupling reactions with yields comparable to or exceeding those of commercial Pd/C. The low yield in the Mizoroki-Heck reaction for both catalysts with bromobenzene as a substrate can be attributed to its lower reactivity. Future studies will focus on the palladium content in the biocatalyst, the characteristics of the microorganisms themselves and their growing conditions, and the influence of the catalyst preparation method on the size, distribution, and catalytic activity of nanoparticles. To compare the catalytic activity of the prepared Pd/P. yeei with analogues described in the literature, TON and TOF values were calculated for the carried reactions. The TON and TOF values of our Pd/P. yeei catalyst were compared with Pd/bio catalysts previously reported in literature [60,85,86]. The TON values of Pd/P. yeei were in range from 12 to 97. TOF values of Pd/P. yeei were in range from 2.4 to 32.3 h−1. Comparing these results with those of a previously reported biohybrid Pd/Cupriavidus necator catalyst [85] we found a good alignment in activity levels for the reaction of 4-iodomethylbenzoate with butylacrylate, while slightly lower values were noted for reactions involving iodobenzene and butylacrylate. However, in the Suzuki-Miyaura reaction, the TON values for Pd/P. yeei were observed to be higher. TOF for Pd/P. yeei is higher than for Pd/C. necator, which is due to a longer synthesis time than in this work. There is work on the use of the fungus Phanerochaete chrysosporium [86], the obligate aerobic bacterium Arthrobacter oxidans and the facultative anaerobic bacterium Cupriavidus metallidurans [60]. TON and TOF values in these works exceed those for Pd/P. yeei. It is important to mention that specific optimization of reaction conditions with a focus on TON and TOF [87] was not performed in the current study, nor in the previously cited literature on biohybrid catalysts. The discussion presented here serves as an initial assessment to establish the general feasibility of the system based on bacterial support. Of course, further investigations may explore different substituents in Pd/bacteria-catalyzed reactions. The data provided here are fundamental for assessing reaction performance, as recently summarized [88]. The similarity in yields between the classical Pd/C and the novel biotechnological Pd/P. yeei catalysts is a key factor. Existing synthetic tools may be applied to adapt Pd/P. yeei to a broader range of substrates. 2.7 Recycling test For the recycling tests in this work, we employed previously described methods [89]. According to the “Fresh Start” approach, after the completion of the catalytic reaction and yield estimation via NMR or GC–MS, all components of the system, except for the catalyst, were reloaded into the reaction vessel with a fresh portion of solvent, and the reaction was repeated. This procedure was conducted the required number of times, with yields determined after each reaction cycle. Alternatively, in the “Catalyst Separation” approach, following reaction completion, the precipitate was separated, washed, dried, and then re-examined for catalytic activity by being introduced into a new reaction mixture containing all reaction components except for the catalyst. This process was similarly repeated after each reaction. Two variations of catalyst separation were used. In the first method, the precipitate was collected at the bottom of the test tube by centrifugation post-reaction, the solution was removed, and the insoluble fraction was washed with various solvents (3 × 10 cm3 each of benzene, toluene, EtOH, acetone, and water), followed by drying to a constant mass in a drying chamber at 100 °C (version A). In the second method, post-reaction, the precipitate was separated by filtration, washed, dried to a constant mass, and then added to a fresh reaction mixture (see Supporting Information for details). The product yields were determined after each cycle (Fig. 7 ). Despite some decrease in the yields of cross-coupling reaction products, the efficiency of the biohybrid catalyst remained good, with reaction yields mostly above 80–85%, even after five repetitions. Pd leaching from the support during cross-coupling reactions, especially in the Mizoroki-Heck reaction with aryl iodides at high temperatures of 120…140 °C, is a common occurrence [87]. To study catalyst leaching, we analyzed the reaction mixture by ICP-MS post-reaction for the Mizoroki-Heck (iodobenzene and styrene) and Suzuki-Miyaura (iodobenzene and 4-methylboronic acid) reactions. The data indicated palladium species leaching into the solution at ∼0.1–0.2 mg/ml, approximately 100 ppm. This behavior is consistent with the “cocktail”-type dynamics typical for Pd-catalyzed cross-coupling reactions, where metal species can oscillate between precipitating back to the support and leaching into the solution. The dynamic catalytic system involves leached Pd species in solution, with the support playing a crucial role in preventing rapid aggregation and deactivation towards Pd black. The nanostructure of Pd/P. yeei catalyst after the fifth cycle of the Mizoroki-Heck or Suzuki-Miyaura reaction was examined using BF-STEM technique (see Figures S16 and S17 in Supporting Information). Post-multiple cycles, the size of the palladium particles increased significantly compared to the freshly prepared biohybrid material. After the Mizoroki-Heck reaction, the metallic phase remained loosely aggregated and mainly consisted of round-shaped particles with sizes of approximately 5–10 nm. In contrast, BF-STEM images of Pd/P. yeei post-Suzuki-Miyaura reaction showed palladium particles approximately 5–15 nm in size, with distorted shapes and significant aggregation. The biosupported catalyst underwent notable changes but retained its relative integrity after the Mizoroki-Heck reaction, preventing irreversible particle aggregation. However, following the Suzuki-Miyaura reaction, changes in the catalyst support structure were more critical, leading to irreversible aggregation of palladium. The transformation of the palladium phase during the Mizoroki-Heck or Suzuki-Miyaura reaction observed in BF-STEM images was independently confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD). Analysis of the XRD pattern for the initial Pd/P. yeei sample allowed one to conclude that the main palladium-containing phase in the sample was Pd (0) (see Supporting information for details). PdO and Pd(OAc)2, which were detected by XPS in the freshly prepared biohybrid catalyst, probably form a surface phase or are present in minor quantities in the sample, which makes it impossible to detect them using XRD. The observed XRD pattern for Pd/P. yeei material isolated after the Mizoroki-Heck reaction was somewhat different. The relative increase in the intensity of Pd (0) peaks and their notable narrowing after five consecutive cycles of the Mizoroki-Heck reaction confirm an increase in the size of the particles due to their cintering under reaction conditions. 2.8 Leaching of palladium from cells. Heterogeneous vs. Homogeneous contributions to catalysis? The results obtained, described in the previous paragraph, indicate the processes of leaching of the catalyst from the cell surface. To make an insight into reaction mechanism, we carried out an experiment similar to the one described in the article [90]. The experiment included two test tubes: the first contained all substances necessary for the Mizoroki-Heck reaction. After heating for 10 min at 140 °C, the catalyst was removed from the first test tube, washed with a solvent (details in Supporting Information), and then transferred to another reaction mixture without catalyst in the second test tube. Both test tubes were heated for 5 h at 140 °C. The product content in both systems was analyzed (after 10 min and 5 h of heating for the first test tube; after 5 h of heating for the second test tube) (Fig. 8 ). The results (Fig. 8) showed product accumulation in both mixtures. The formation of the product in reaction mixture 1 may be related to the leaching of Pd from the cell surface into the solution. This is confirmed by the above analysis by the ICP-MS method at the recycle test. It appears that not all Pd leached into the solution within 10 min, as the product formation in reaction mixture 2 was associated with the catalytic activity of the transferred heterogeneous catalyst. The experiment demonstrated the “cocktail”-type nature of the catalytic system [23]. It is important to emphasize that leaching is a reversible process, and may be followed by metal deposition at the reaction's completion. A sequence of leaching and precipitation occurs, with the support surface playing a crucial role in preventing rapid aggregation and deactivation of the catalyst. 2.9 Robustness test To establish the tolerance or sensitivity of Pd/C-based catalysts to the presence of microorganisms in the reaction mixture, all components of the catalytic system were mixed with a substantial amount of bacterial cells, significantly exceeding the loadings of biohybrid catalysts in previous experiments. The mixtures were then stirred and heated for the preselected reaction duration (Scheme 1). After reaction completion, the products were isolated, and their yields and purity were estimated by NMR analysis. The experiment revealed that the Suzuki-Miyaura reaction is insensitive to the presence of microorganisms in the reaction mixture, proceeding with an almost quantitative yield (Table 2 ). However, for the Mizoroki-Heck reaction, the presence of a large quantity of bacterial cells notably reduced the yield of stilbene, which did not exceed 33 % (Table 2). We propose that for some reason, microorganisms in high content are able to reduce the catalytic activity of palladium nanoparticles. This effect was not observed in aqueous solutions or when using catalytic amounts of biohybrid materials. It is possible that this phenomenon is related to the potential ability of microorganisms to capture Pd nanoparticles from Pd/C in a nonaqueous DMF solution, thereby decreasing its catalytic activity. This interesting phenomenon warrants further detailed investigation in future studies. 3 Conclusions In this study, we demonstrated the principal possibility of using aerobic Paracoccus yeei VKM B-3302 cells as a support for palladium nanoparticles, resulting in the preparation of a novel biohybrid Pd/P. yeei catalyst. This catalyst exhibited good activity in practically relevant reactions, and, with a range of studies performed, provided deeper insights into the potential of bacterial cells as supports for Pd nanoparticles. Experiments indicated that microbial cells in the reaction mixture neither hindered the reaction process nor contributed to side reactions, allowing complete conversion of starting materials and high yields of reaction products. These yields were comparably efficient to those obtained with commercial Pd/C. Thus, we have demonstrated that the bacterial cells of Paracoccus yeei do not interact with the starting substances and reaction products. Notably, the results from the robustness test suggest that, under certain conditions cells can reduce the catalytic activity of Pd nanoparticles in nonaqueous solutions, possibly due to the capture of active metal species leached from the carbon support. The Pd on a bacterial substrate demonstrated the ability to maintain catalytic activity over several repeated cycles, likely involving a dynamic “cocktail”-type catalytic system with leaching and redeposition. This hypothesis was supported by an experiment aimed at determining contributions of heterogeneous vs. homogeneous pathways to catalysis. Additionally, the formation of nanoparticles both inside and outside bacterial cells was observed, with intracellular localization leading to a greater number of smaller-diameter nanoparticles. Future studies will focus on refining and standardizing new methods for preparing metal species with varied sizes and distributions. This will help in understanding the patterns of particle accumulation in different cells and their organelles, and how these factors influence the catalytic activity of nanoparticles in classic palladium-catalyzed reactions. It is important to highlight that combining biotechnological approaches with well-developed knowledge in catalyst design can open multiple fascinating opportunities in the development of new generations of catalysts. The use of supported biohybrid metal/bacteria catalysts with nanoscale particles on and inside microbial cells is a promising direction for future research. While the described support material exhibits certain advantageous properties, it is crucial to recognize that heterogeneous catalysis is influenced by various factors, including the nature of the process, reaction conditions, temperature, and the presence of potential poisons or promoters, among others. The performance of a material in one specific reaction does not guarantee similar efficacy in another. Therefore, additional comprehensive evaluations are essential before generalizing the catalytic utility of this material across a range of reactions. We anticipate that the potential of bacterial biomass as a support for heterogeneous catalysts will be thoroughly explored in future research. CRediT authorship contribution statement Pavel V. coredata.dc:description: Palladium-based catalysts are of key importance in organic synthesis due to their versatility and tolerance for a wide range of functional groups. However, their use challenged by increasing sustainability issues and complex preparation methods. Consequently, the development of new heterogeneous catalysts with enhanced sustainability is of significant interest. Typically, the synthesis of carbon supports for palladium is associated with high energy consumption or the generation of substantial chemical waste, prompting extensive research into the creation of sustainable biological supports. In this study, the potential use of aerobic bacterial cells as a support for palladium nanoparticles was explored, using Paracoccus yeei VKM B-3302 as a model organism. Electron microscopy, powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) studies demonstrated the formation of palladium particles on the cell surface as well as inside microorganisms following deposition from a solution. Control experiments established that bacterial cells do not interact with either the reactants or the products of selected cross-coupling processes. Furthermore, bacteria do not affect the analysis of reaction mixtures by nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy and gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS). At the same time, palladium/Paracoccus yeei demonstrated efficient catalysis of the Mizoroki-Heck and Suzuki-Miyaura reactions, yielding results comparable to commercial palladium on carbon (Pd/C) catalysts. Employing a fresh start procedure and catalyst separation method, the catalyst was successfully recycled and reused across five cycles, maintaining good catalytic activity. In a broader aspect, bacteria-supported biohybrid palladium catalysts can represent a new type of catalysts worth to explore in a number of processes, where sustainability issues are concerned.
coredata.dc:title: Aerobic bacteria-supported biohybrid palladium catalysts for efficient cross-coupling reactions
